awd_titl_txt: The Genetic History of the Aleut People
awd_abstract_narration:
In recent years, ancient DNA research has transformed our understanding of human history. In the Americas, ancient genomes have revealed new and surprising details, such as the presence of previously unknown populations, previously unsuspected relationships between groups, and new estimates of dates for past events in human history.  Although recent studies have investigated the origins and history of different Native American groups, few have focused on the indigenous peoples of the Aleutian Islands, a population that may prove central to our understanding of human dispersals in the western hemisphere. The analysis of genomes from ancient and contemporary Aleuts will allow us to better understand the origins of these peoples, how they adapted to a challenging environment, and how European contact and recent population events have affected their genetic diversity. This research is supported by Aleut political and cultural leaders, who are interested in using genetic approaches to better understand their people's history. Results from this project will be used in education materials for the participating communities, as well as in initiatives designed to train Native American students in genetics. 

The Americas were the last continents to become inhabited by humans, but it has recently become clear that the history of this process was far more complicated than originally understood based on archaeology alone. For example, current archaeological evidence suggests that the Aleutian Islands were peopled approximately 9,000 years ago in a series of population movements from the Alaska Peninsula westward, with groups inhabiting the western islands by about 3,000 years ago. A recently published analysis of genomic-scale data from ancient and contemporary peoples of the Arctic, which includes data from a few ancient individuals from the Eastern Aleutian islands, indicates that the Aleutian gene pool dates to approximately 5,000 years ago, leaving a 4,000 year discrepancy between archaeological and genetic records. One hypothesis to resolve the discrepancy between the genetic and archaeological dates holds that the earliest ancestors of Native Americans - who lived in Beringia approximately 20,000 years ago - may have moved southward to the Alaska Peninsula, eventually peopling the present-day central and western islands. The investigators will test this hypothesis and uncover additional details of the history of the peopling of the Aleutian Islands through the analysis of complete genomes from ancient and contemporary Aleuts. They will also assess the demographic effects of European contact beginning in the 18th century on Aleut populations, and characterize the genetic adaptations of ancient and contemporary Aleuts to the challenging environmental conditions present in the archipelago over time. This research was developed in a partnership between Aleut political and cultural leadership and the researchers at the University of Kansas, which is the result of a decades-long collaboration. This project is jointly funded by the Biological Anthropology Programs, the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR), and the Arctic Social Science Program at the National Science Foundation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Aleutian Islands were one of the last places on Earth to be inhabited by humans. The easternmost islands were settled by the ancestors of the Unangax̂, the present-day Indigenous peoples of the Aleutian Islands, 9,000 years ago. The westernmost islands were not occupied until roughly 3,000 years ago. The Unangax̂ developed a rich culture, strongly tied to the ocean, rivers, and marine animals and plants. They have thrived for thousands of years in a challenging and ever-changing sub-Arctic marine environment.

The Unangax̂ experienced more recent European contact/colonization than Indigenous groups throughout the rest of the Americas, with the late arrival of Russian fur traders and fishers in 1741. In the subsequent 300 years of colonization, the Unangax̂ endured forced migration, disease, war, and forced assimilation. Despite this turbulent history, they maintain strong traditional connections to their Ancestors’ language, knowledge, and ways of living.

The events which impacted the lives of the Unangax̂ also shaped their genetic variation. Thus, the study of genomes from ancient and living Unagax can help us address historical and cultural questions. In this project, we have generated the largest dataset to date of ancient and contemporary Unangax̂ genomes, spanning their complete geographic distribution, and generated stable isotope data and 33 radiocarbon dates from Unangax̂ Ancestors.

We were given permission by the Native Village of Atka, the federally recognized tribe that has sovereignty over the western Aleutian Islands, to conduct research on the genomes of their Ancestors in order to investigate their population history. These Ancestors were removed from their burial places between 1936-1938 and were curated by the Smithsonian Institution until their repatriation back to descendants. Prior to their reburial, we were allowed to take small samples from the Ancestors in order to ascertain when they lived (via radiocarbon dating) what they ate (through the analysis of stable isotopes), and their genetic variation.

We have also, with permission, characterized the genomes of 5 living individuals who represent ancestries from throughout the Aleutian archipelago as well as varying degrees of admixture from outside groups.

Previous genomic work has shown that Unangax̂ ancestors (dating 2300-50 calBP) from the eastern islands had a gene pool composed of a majority ancestry component shared with Paleo-Inuit (Saqqaq) and a minority ancestry component shared with all Indigenous peoples of the Americas (First Peoples). However, the genetic composition of ancient inhabitants of the western islands has been unclear, limiting our understanding of the initial peopling and subsequent population histories of the archipelago. Here we utilized paleogenomic data from Unangax̂ ancestors (whole genomes; average depth of coverage 0.25-3.4X) that lived in the central and western islands from 2750-260 cal BP. We use this dataset to examine the relationships of these individuals to other Arctic groups, and to re-estimate Paleo-Inuit-related and First Peoples-related ancestry in the combined gene pool.

 Our findings support and expand upon insights gleaned from prior, smaller-scale genomics studies, and are the first to explicitly investigate the consequences of European contact and colonization in this region. Ongoing analyses will add additional details of ancient and contemporary population history which we will integrate with ethnographic, archaeological, historical data, and community knowledge.
